page.title: 02Hedgerows in the Blackdowns.
page.content: A hundred metres of hedgerow bordering a road on a 16% slope were to contain the following eleven species: oak,ash, blackthorn, hawthorn, sycamore, field-maple, hazel, holly, willow, elm and elder. Other woody species in nearby hedges are wild cherry and dogwood. Ivy,bramble and rose scramble among the shrubs. This road and others like it almost certainly existed when the first Domesday book was compiled. In contrast some hedgerows on the plateau are almost pure beech,and these date from early 19th century enclosures.The sides and tops of these hedgebanks form a habitat for many wild flowers.Among the most conspicuous are bluebells in May, foxgloves in June and rosebay willow herb in July. Ferns are abundant on the shadier hedgebanks, particularly polypody,soft shield and male ferns.
